text: all right so my name again is Dave
Johnson I run informatics for Moderne so
my job is to support all of research
from preclinical through clinical with
digital and automation and abling
solutions and while lab of the future is
a heavy-lift to live up to I'm going to
do my best here and talk about the work
that we've done of the last time of
years around high-throughput production
of a preclinical mRNA if you're not
familiar with Moderne what we're trying
to do is build a whole new class of
medicines based around mRNA technology
the central dogma of biology is that the
information to create every protein in
your body is encoded in your DNA mRNA is
what carries that information from the
nucleus out to the ribosomes those will
then produce whatever protein they're
instructed to and so what Mandarin is
trying to do is we create our own
synthetic messenger RNA that encodes
whatever protein that we instruct it to
that gets carry to the ribosomes in the
cell we typically encode soup networks
we typically wrap those mRNAs inside of
a lipid nanoparticle which you can see
here that when it reaches the cell will
inject the mRNA into the cell the
ribosomes grab it and then print off
whatever they're instructed to what's
really cool about this is with the same
technology the same process just with
mRNA where we encode different
information on that we can produce a
variety of different kinds of proteins
so you can see here secreted proteins
transmembrane proteins mitochondria are
nuclear proteins anything your body can
produce we can encode that into an mRNA
we can also encode all sorts of other
things like antigens to create vaccines
so anything at all that we can encode
we'll put into an mRNA what this gives
us is a really flexible programmable
platform for creating medicines and what
we've done is in the short lifetime of
what is a rather small company in this
industry we've amassed a rather huge
pipeline a really unprecedented for the
size what we have we have 22 candidates
and development right now most advanced
of which is veg F which is part
ship with Astra Zeneca and phase 2 but
we have prophylactic vaccines we have
two different cancer vaccines one of
which is a personalized cancer vaccine
where we sequence an individual patient
and produce a vaccine just for that
patient
we have intro to rural we have localized
regenerative we have systemic secreted
intracellular as well anything that we
can think of and target we are actively
pursuing so you can see there's just a
huge variety of different applications
across our development pipeline here if
you look at the 10-year vision of the
company our goal is not unsurprisingly
is to be the leading MRNA company and we
continue to invest in that we invested
heavily for the future we'll continue to
do that working with our partners to
discover and develop a huge breadth of
meaningful vaccines and therapeutics but
the next one was really key for me as a
part of the digital function is that we
integrate automation and digital
technology into everything we do it's
not just in certain isolated areas it's
not just manufacturing it's across
research across the business across
finance wherever we can apply it we do
that too far and we think about digital
and how it applies there's a number of
foundational building blocks that we use
we start with the cloud obviously we're
heavily based in AWS they wouldn't have
invited us here if it wasn't for that
but we've been in AWS user from the
early days very earlier on in the
company we started using it and our
mantra is to put as much in the cloud as
we can to leverage the benefits of that
shared infrastructure we do of course
have some on Prem stuff for low latency
activities and storage for instruments
that we have to have but whatever we can
we push it to the cloud it goes beyond
infrastructure we also work with all of
our software vendors who have SAS
solutions we tend to prefer SAS
providers let them host and manage their
own infrastructure we'll they'll do a
better job of that than we can do the
next level is integration which is
almost always forgotten about in the
enterprise
we have probably hundreds of different
applications and where we can we
integrate that data together it's very
uncommon
that an application exists in a silo
where its data is just for itself right
so what happens if you don't integrate
as you have humans people putting the
same information at every single
different system which is incredibly
error-prone but it's also incredibly
tedious for those users and so you end
up doing things like offshoring that
activity looking at our PA because you
should have just integrated it in the
first place and we do this everywhere we
see some of them are more advanced
integrations and things like onboarding
people onboarding new people when we
hire them right that's information needs
to touch dozens of different systems so
we have one user record that's input and
it floods out to the various different
systems next move into Internet of
Things which any kinds of devices and it
can a pcs and manufacturing any kind of
sensors we have a bunch of amazon iot
buttons that we use for inventory
replenishment and manufacturing so any
dumb device that we can get connected to
the internet we will select data they
move into more sophisticated automation
robotics platforms and I'll talk about
some of this later with the liquid
handling robots these are much more
sophisticated robotic platforms with
kind of movable arms and with little
pipettes that can take instructions and
relay data back and then finally move
into the analytics and AI space where we
take all that data that we're collecting
from our data capture systems and
process automation we reflect that back
to the users in terms of just basic
reports basic metrics kpi's then we
start to get into more advanced
applications and algorithms we were
starting to make decisions on behalf of
the users and take them out of the loop
and a lot of cases I'll touch on some of
that so as I said I'm responsible for
supporting research and if you look in
the kind of early stages of research
this is kind of a cartoon of what this
cycle looks like right a scientist would
formulate a hypothesis about some target
they might be interested in and trying
some mRNA for here's a protein I think
that would work really well for this
disease so they formulate that
hypothesis then they need some mRNA to
test that so they'd have to go and
synthesize create the messenger RNA for
that they'll run an experiment to see
what the outcome of that is they'll
evaluate that those results will tell
them what to do next right do I run
another one do I
I'm abandon this and try something else
so there's bottlenecks across all of
this but you know very early on in the
life of the company we identified
synthesis of mRNA being one particularly
ugly bottleneck that could slow this
process down and five years ago we did
make the decision right away to say we
should centralize this right so we have
one group this preclinical production
group who's responsible for producing
mRNA on behalf of the rest of the
company but it was a very manual process
with you know the staff that we had at
the time and the process the way it was
we were limited about 40 unique mRNAs in
a month now it's 40 new drugs right
potentially in a month so it's still
pretty good
but it wasn't great and we knew we could
do better so we wanted to do is really
accelerate the pace of research by doing
better in this space so we thought if we
could decrease the synthesis time to
make it faster from what a scientist
says I need an mRNA so when we get that
mRNA that lets them perform that cycle
over again they get their experiment
done faster to get the results faster
they can move on faster if we can
increase the quality in the consistency
of the mRNA we take out the guesswork
from a scientist when they get a bad
experimental result they're not saying
well was it a bad experiment or was it
bad mRNA right we take that out of the
picture and we let them run repeat
experiments where they run six months
later and they can actually trust that
the mRNA that got that time is
equivalent to what it was before and
then finally most importantly if we can
increase throughput we can dramatically
improve this so instead of having only
40 scientists who could actually ask the
question a month we can have many more
ask it we can have a scientist test
multiple hypotheses at once right and
maybe here's five different targets I'm
interested in we also do a lot of code
on optimization where we are actually
mutating the the mRNA to change the
nucleotides but leave the protein the
same such that we get different
expression or different
manufacturability and so letting the
scientists run an entire panel of code
and optimize variants and see which one
works best so by driving these three
points so we can really dramatically
improve the pace of research so fast
forward to to where we are today we've
been
for a bit now we have this
high-throughput preclinical production
facility it was in Cambridge actually
unbent Street but we recently last year
moved into our new Norwood manufacturing
facility it's a two hundred thousand
square foot manufacturing facility
that's mostly dedicated to GMP
manufacturing no the second floor this
facility there's a space carved out
where we've moved in our preclinical
production you can see here on the
bottom it's heavily robotic process lots
of robots and cool instruments there and
as opposed to 40 mRNAs a month we now
have the capacity producing up to a
thousand unique mRNA never before made
ever in a month to do this we have lots
of robots and lots of robotic pieces
equipment but we have quite a few that
are actually integrated in terms of web
service integrations the workhorse we
have our Hamilton liquid handling robots
which are these gray boxes up here these
are kind of general-purpose liquid
handling platforms can reconfigure the
deck you can attach different equipment
on the sides of these and they take
variable instructions for what to do we
have 13 of these active and production
across the company probably have over 20
of them within production alone we have
65 different methods there's 65
different kind of unit operations that
these robots perform things like
preparing a plate for an assay we have a
bunch of zebra label printers we have
three of these robotic freezers that
store tubes of material at various
stages in the process we have 2 - 80
Hamilton Sam freezers and one - 20 like
Connick freezer the frustrating thing
about all of these they're all
integrated but they all speak an
entirely different language the
Hamiltons don't have any notion of a web
service but they can actually make
outgoing HTTP calls to get information
the zebra label printers expose a TCP
socket you can connect to the Sam
Hamilton freezers they expose a soap API
and the like Annika exposes a REST API
so we have four different integration
techniques here that we have to just
deal with but it's better than most of
the instruments which don't integrate at
all so
we made an early decision to push as
much of the logic as we can into the web
application layer and the reason for
that is because deploying 65 different
methods across 13 different lab pcs is a
real pain in the neck to get done we've
done a lot of work just to keep them up
to date with the methods the way they
are but we have lots of frequent changes
that we do and so it's a huge challenge
to do that so instead we push as much up
into the web application layer so what
tips to use where to put materials what
materials to use what incubation times
all of that it kept up in the web
application layer and we keep the
methods as dumb as possible so that they
don't have to be changed as much and
it's a two-way stream the Hamiltons will
reach out and say what am I supposed to
be doing they will do those activities
and they often have attached quality
control instruments like concentration
or pH meters that are directly attached
to them and they'll feed that data back
up for capture and analysis on the right
here you can see some screenshots of the
plate maps from the web application
which is instructing the Hamiltons
exactly what a pipette different
materials the different colors here is
not show but the different colors here
indicate different orders from
scientists so this is a graphical
picture of a 96-well plate it's about
that big with 96 little buckets that we
make mRNA in depending on the order you
get more or less wells on that plate and
they get pooled together at the end and
what's really cool here is the different
colors are different orders so the first
one might be in oncology drug the next
one might be a vaccine the next one
might be a rare disease all running
together through the same process at
once and on the right there you just see
the next scale up which is much larger
in these larger lab wear so this
application that communicates and drives
this production process is actually part

informatics applications that we have
these are built in a microservices based

just part of them we have applications

mRNA
it starts really at this mrna design

I want this one with these attributes

it's integrated with our finance system
si P so it's all internal use it but we

integrates with those robotic

all of these applications are deployed

Fargate it's an early adopter here and

across all of the services we have we

the different applications we have a

this picture is everything has multiple

automatically gets replaced
and it does happen it's just randomness
of it and so we don't have to think

which we used to have to deal with we
don't think about disk running out on

applications to support the business so
the last thing I want to do here is dig
into one particular example of how we do
kind of data integration automation now
across this whole production process and
across the company we have numerous
algorithms numerous automated processes
but I wanted to dig into one just so you
can kind of see end to end what one
looks like and then show you what what
an ROI for one of these is so we do a
lot of saying or sequencing analysis
like a lot if you're familiar with NGS
singers the old generation sequencing
but it's still heavily used by any DNA
based a protein based RNA based company
is a really cost effective way to
quality-control sequences and to verify
that sequence actually is the DNA
sequence it's supposed to be and it
doesn't have any mutations so the way it
works is you you have some sample of DNA
and you run it through a sequencer that
sequencer will run through a thermal
cycle process to extend the mRNA with
these die capped ends and then we run it
through capillary electrophoresis and
shine lasers on it and what you get is
these peaks of intensity that show that
signify the different bases and so then
you can just read off that's an AC G or
T right that data is noisy like all data
and also only covers part of the
sequence you usually only get about five
to seven hundred good bases read out of
it so you know staggering these reads
across in both directions so in order to
make sense of that data you actually
have to run it through some software
that will identify all the peaks they'll
call the peaks it'll line them all up
together it'll say what is the consensus
as to compare to what it's supposed to
be in say oh I found a mistake this base
is not what it's supposed to be and then
it'll pass or fail the sample right now
the challenge is and this is how we did
it in the early days this software is
almost always wind
based software with a graphical
interface so a user or an operator would
essentially have to take a zip file that
comes back from the vendor who runs the
assay for us and in there is every
single well of a 96-well plate some 96
different data files they have to pull
out the ones that are relevant to just
that sample load into the software go
get a FASTA file loaded in the software
and then run the analysis and then
decide what to do this is a hugely
manual tedious process and on top of
that we're at kind of a level of control
here where the software doesn't look for
things that were concerned with we're
really concerned about et bitty little
problems like mutations in a
subpopulation of the DNA rather than an
all of it I'm in a bunch of other little
edge cases that we've run into and so
that off-the-shelf software doesn't
really work for us so what we did is we
built this automated data processing
framework for just saying or sequencing
over here on the Left we have a
sequencing vendor who actually runs the
assays we send them plates of samples
and they'll run it through their
sequencers and we do this outside of the
house because it's it's really a
commodity to run Sanger so you can go
for the the cheapest supplier for that
what they do is we actually give them a
I am credential to load that data
directly into our s3 bucket at the end
so they have a lim system that will push
that data up the moment it hits it
triggers an s3 event that event gets
pushed into an sqs queue just to
work.you of all the samples that need to
be run all the data files this saying
our app will then read that message that
says hey go process this data you know
pull the zip file out and then it'll
open the zip up find the reasons that
are relevant tie it together with the
data and then it submits it to this
internal clustering software we have
that will spin up spot instances on
demand as many as we need to process the
data in parallel and then we'll run a
proprietary Sanger QC algorithm that we
have running in docker containers that
will then process that data and make a
pass/fail call the results of that are
pushed into an sqs queue for receipt
back the application pulls it forward
and then it'll go to the production app
and say hey that lot of material is
failed just kill it off
so the numbers here as I said we run a
lot of Sanger a typical day run three or
four hundred samples through three and
four hundred analyses over the last four
we've run over two hundred thousand
analysis that's over two million

if you do back-of-the-envelope

higher than that but we also get much

it's consistent it's always the same and
so what does this all cost right it is I
didn't I didn't look up the the storage
cost because that would be the same
regardless of the solution but I looked
at what the compute cost is for the
dynamic scaling of this over the last
four years and it comes to about a
hundred bucks it's not typo it's a
hundred dollars and that's because we
just leverage spot instances for all of
this and we spin them up only when we
need it right so these 400 analyses come
in we spin up servers for brief period
shut them down and they're gone so that
gives you a sense of what the ROI looks
like in this and this is one example of
